Notes: The Kui-Kuwi forms are probably borrowed from Telugu, because geminated-ḍḍ-is not usually reconstructed for PGn.

The Konda form unexpectedly changed conjugation type (aṭ-can only go back to*aḍ-C-). Vowel length in PK is irregular; as a matter of fact, Kuwi_Su has shorta-, so this variant is probably more archaic.

The root was heavily used with posessive prefixes. The most frequent form is*yay-'my mother'. In some dialects this form became generalized, with the following shift of meaning: 'my mother' > 'mother in general', 'mother' > 'woman'. A new form, based on the 1st person pl. pronoun (Gondimāy-, Kuwimāya) resulted from the loss of initialy-and the secondary merger of the simple and the prefixed forms.

Additional Forms: Also Pengoaya-taṛiwoman;teyafemale of animal;teyhimother (related to 3rd person); Mandatayafemale of animal
Notes: In Manda two protoforms (*yay-originally meaning 'my mother') merged phonetically.

This deictic base had the following declineable forms in PGn:*aw-ant_[-u](whence Gondi*ōn-R, Kondavānr_uwith a metathese, etc.) 'that man', plural*aw-ar[-u]'those men'; fem.*a-d-i(PK*ādiby analogy with masculine forms), plural*a-v-i. Also reconstructed for the PGn level is*a-c-'that many, that much' (PG, PPM, PK);*a-tal'that side' (Konda, PK, possibly Gondi);*a-mb-/*a-b-'there' (Konda, PPM, PK).  An enormous number of derivatives has been formed independently in different languages (which is characteristic of all deictic bases).

Meaning: that man, those men, that woman, those women, that thing, those things
Additional Forms: Also Pengo adj.ā,āy,anda;andelthat woman;andaŋthat thing;andaliŋfor that, for that reason;acaka,ace,acekthat big, so big;anṭaŋ,anṭiŋin that direction;anṭiŋtan,anṭiŋdanfrom that direction;aniover there;aneŋthus, in that way;abe,habe,ambethere;aleŋthus, in that way; ?anaymuch (? that much)

Notes: The root existed in PK only with the suffix*-nj-.
Bisyllabic root.

Additional Forms: Also Pengolap-(-t-) to insert, fit into (tr.)

Notes: An isolated Pengo form that nevertheless corresponds rather well to PDR*ala-(especially in the light of such forms as Tam.ala-mpu, etc.).
The Gondi semantic shift to 'father' can be connected with the "extra" suffix-l.
The root probably contaminated with*a[n]ṭ-'to stick', whence the meaning in PPM.
Possibly more than one root involved; unfortunately, Gondwan reflexes of former bisyllabic verbal bases with a vocalic anlaut are quite poorly studied.

The Kui-Kuwi forms can easily be traced back to a former transitive verbal stem (*ará-t-< PDR*ari-+*-t-). More problematic is Pengoraz-, which should normally go back to*arád_-. It is unclear if this is a real alternate stem or an irregular development in a non-trivial context.
Bisyllabic root.

Additional Forms: Also Pengovēṛa arbonḍsetting of the sun, west;rat-(-t-) to let fall, drop; motionratka-; intens.ratpa-; Mandaret-to let fall, drop
Notes: Mandare-is an analogical back-formation fromre-t-; the Pengo oppositionar-/ra-t-is probably more archaic.
Causative type of conjugation in PGn.
A questionable etymology with unique correspondences between Konda and PPM; the exact match in semantics, however, suggests that Burrow & Emeneau's comparison is valid. See also external parallels.

Notes on correspondences: PGn*-ṛ> Konda-l(-ṛin some dialects). In some Kui-Kuwi dialects the plural form has been generalised.

Notes: Bisyllabic root. In Konda and PPM it was used with a suffix: *āñd_ur-ka > *ānd_r-ka > *ānd_-ga, *ānd_-i-ka. In PK reduction of the second syllable led to a general simplification of the cluster.

Meaning: to intercept, hold back, hold up

Notes: Causative conjugation only.

Meaning: to put on (coat, on another), fix (load on carrying-yoke)
Additional Forms: Also Pengoarpiyā-(<arpiya ā-) to put on, wear (coat)

Notes: The word was frequently used apluralia tantum, whence PPM and PG*ārku<*ārg-ku(cf. also Kuiārka).
It is hard to say whether in PK-k-was lost for phonetical or morphological reasons. If nasalisation in some Kuwi dialects is not secondary (bā̃vli), it may be a trace of an old nasalised velar.

The exact nature of the inlaut cluster (phoneme?) is hard to determine: PK and PPM show*-r-, Konda speaks in favor of*-ṛ-, while Gondi gives several variants (*-y-,*-r-,*-l-; one dialect even has a unique*-ḷ-).
Causative conjugation in PGn (which explains voiceless reflexes everywhere).

PPMj-is not quite clear. It can only be explained through assimilation (*sāc->*cāc-)  and then (!) dissimilation (*cāc->jāc-). The root itself had a velar suffix in its intransitive form (*sā-ŋ-) and a palatal causative suffix (*sā-c-).
In DED PPM and PK forms are erroneously compared with SDR*cāy-'to incline'; this is impossible because of the initial consonant.

Most of the seeming irregularities in this root's reflexation are the result of its joining with the root*vā-'to come' (*ey-v-). This form is seen in Gondi*ev-(and not*ey-) and PK*ey-v-. In PPM the old suffixal form*ey-k(probably a nominal derivative) was also used only withvā-. Kondaī-is irregular as well; maybe developed from*eyv-.
Initialn-in Manda is irregular and rather strange. The samen-is found in Dongriya Kuwi,  but still, the evidence is too few to reconstruct something other than an initial vowel.
Bisyllabic root.

Facultative vowel length in Pengo can probably point to a different reconstruction (especially since  inlaut*-n-goes back to a cluster because of the causative type of conjugation), but the variant with*e-should at  least be present in PPM as facultative.

Additional Forms: Also Pengoēt-(-t-) to make to dance, make (top) spin; Manda intens.ētka-

Notes: There were actually several 'hook'-roots in PGn (see also*kōnḍ-; one should also probably reconstruct*kok-, cf. Gondikokkihoe, etc.), and naturally they all hopeleslly contaminated with each other. That is why we have Konda and PK*k-.

Additional Forms: Also Pengogok-(-t-) to bend, twist;gomga- (road) to go crookedly (motion base only)

Notes: The reasons for such obviously irregular reflexation in all dialects except PPM are a) assimilations  (*-m->-p-through assimilation with*g-) and b) contamination with*kup-'mound,  hillock'. However, such forms as Pengogomoṇclearly point to a different root. There is also a strange Kuwi_Su formgu'uwith an unclear glottal stop. Were it possible to trace it back to*gumu(?), the PK reconstruction should have been altered.
Different assimilations in both languages.
The root often contaminated with*kūḍ-'a k. of cage'.

Meaning: to lie down, fall; to sleep
Notes: Initial*k-in Kui is hard to understand. Maybe it is influenced by Telugukuriyu'to rain, shower'; more probably, there has been contamination with*kurk-'to be drowsy, sleep', although the latter is not preserved in Kui.
The declineable forms in PGn are analogical to those formed from*a-(*iwanr_u'this man', etc.).

Additional Forms: Also Pengo adj.ī,inda;ice,icek,icaka(neut. pl.iciŋ,icoŋ) so big, so many, so much;igo,igoynow;inṭaŋin this direction;ini,ibehere;ibṇibelonging to here;ileŋso, in this way;iyonḍaŋ/iyonḍiŋthis year; Mandaīadj. this;icekthis much, so much;inihere;ībaid.;ī̃yuṭthis year

Notes: Inlaut consonant is unclear. In PPM we have causative conjugation, so*iṭ-can possibly <*iḍ-; however, in PK simple forms are present (Kuiiṭa, etc.).
The Konda form goes back to an old suffixal*iṛ-Vy-. The root is not bisyllabic, as shown by PPM.
Bisyllabic root.

Meaning: (water) to sink into the ground, be absorbed

Notes: See also PG*ir-vurtwo (masc.) Bisyllabic root.

Additional Forms: Also Pengorikartwo men;rinḍektwo women;rinḍaŋtwo (neut.); Mandarikartwo men;rikehiŋtwo women
Also Pengoimenakana man belonging to where;imeni(attrib.);imṇakanwho; fem.imṇakadel;imṇiwhat (attrib.); Manda fem.amdel, neut.amdi, masc. pl.amnar, neut. pl.amne

Notes: In Manda an irregular development, probably due to form frequency.
Bisyllabic root, as seen on the basis of Kui-Kuwi and Pengo-Manda data.

Additional Forms: Also Pengo intens.aṛba-; caus.ṛat-; intens. of caus.ṛatpa-

Notes: The word had a PK derivative:*yēt_-ki'thirst' > PG*etk-(with secondary shortening), KondaēRki, PPM*ēski, PK*ēski.

Additional Forms: Also Pengoēs(variant form ofēzused in certain combinations, e.g.ēs orliotter [lit. water-rat]);ēskithirst; Mandaehkithirst
Also Pengokabga-id. (intensive; <kag-ba-);kakohiŋ(pl.) vomit, what is vomited; Manda intens.kabga-

Notes: Vowel lengthening in PPM unclear.
Bisyllabic root.

Loss of retroflex articulation in Manda is not quite clear; it either has something to do with the  auslaut position (although-ṇis not prohibited in the auslaut), or is due to development by analogy with the plural formkanke<*kaṇku.
The root had a PGn derivative*kay-mul'bitter', whereas PKkambli, Mandakembel, etc.
Bisyllabic root.

An ultrashort epenthetical-e-seems to be present already on the PGn level (cf. Gondi vs. Kui forms). However, since there is no development*-e->*-ä-in PK, the root should be reconstructed as monosyllabic.
Pengogajaprobably influenced by or directly borrowed from Telugugaja.

Meaning: to wait for; to watch out for
Notes: Gondi*-ē-is unclear. Maybe the root was reinterpreted as having a*-y-auslaut, in which case*kāy-p->*kē-p-.

Additional Forms: Also Pengokai ki-to wake (tr.); Manda (special base)kāt-(-t-) to watch for, wait for (me, etc.)

Meaning: to warm oneself (in the sun or by the fire)
Additional Forms: Also Mandakānd-(sun) to be hot; to warm oneself in the sun;kāpi ki-to heat, roast

Notes: The word had a causative conjugation in PGn (probably with the suffix*-p-).Hence the loss of  voice in Gondi, Konda and PPM (all these forms go back to*ked_-p->*ket_-; in PPM probably  a 'metathese of voice':*ked_->*get_-). The form*ket_-pi'door' goes back to PGn.
Bisyllabic root with first long vowel.

Pengokitulis a complex form, whereki-is (at least etymologically) the root. Although-Vlis a Pengo suffix, nowhere else do we find the word for ear with a-t-, so we have to  suppose thatkitulis a compound form, with its second part unclear. In Manda the form is  simple; however, we have to explain the secondary voicening. Reconstruction of*kiyis,  therefore, impossible. If we suppose a development of PPM*-v> Manda-y(with no  counterexamples), the voicening should be due to PPM*kiv>*giv>*giy; however, it is more probable that-yis a suffix (like intrey'hair' <ter-y-), sogiy<*kiv-y. Pengokitulin this case goes back to*kiv-tul.
We should expect Mandakerpi< PPM*keirp-; maybe the form is borrowed or dialectal.

The root is almost never used by itself, but always in conjunction with certain parts of body:*kir_l-+ 'leg' = ankle, etc. The correspondences are extremely complex, since it is very hard  to trace PK-rl-, PPM-eir-and Gondi-r-to a single proto-cluster. However, if we  assume this reconstruction, it would be quite possible to compare this form with SDR*kir_-'small' (DEDR 1594), especially since there is an appropriate parallel in Todakɨt_ eɫ̣f'ankle', literally 'small bone'. If we consider*-l-a suffix, the forms are easily explainable.
Inlaut-ɣ-assimilated in most dialects; however, it is usually preserved in the absolute auslaut (like Pengokoy) and seen in Kuikog-.

Meaning: father's younger brother's wife, mother's younger sister
Additional Forms: Also Pengokoglewoman (? originally 'girl');koy/i/(pl.koyik) (small) girl, daughter, sister

Notes: Maybe the root should be joined with*kos-(*kosoy?)

Additional Forms: Also Pengokōd-(kōtt-) to smoke (intr.);kōt-(kōtt-) id. (tr.), burn incense

Notes: Causative conjugation in PGn (so the inlaut consonant is unclear). This root (DEDR 2064) is preceded by DEDR 2063*koṭ-'to strike, beat, crush, thresh, etc.'; however, most of the forms in both entries are identic, and those that are not do not contradict each other. I suppose that this is actually a single root.

Voicening in Konda is easily explainable; however, the inlaut cluster is strange. In PPM there seems to have been desaffricativisation; as for PK, we cannot say for certain whether*-ṭigoes back to*-ri.
The second component, seen in PPM and PK, is unclear: the usual suffix is simple *-ɣ-. Cf. such forms as Tamilkuṛ-āy. Konda-u-unclear; maybe due to back articulation of preceding/following velars.

Such forms as Kuikrōgaor Pengokṛō-could be regarded as pointing to an old bisyllabic root. However, I think that in this case metathese should be attributed to the tendency of cluster elimination, i.e. the structure*koṛv-has a tendency >*kṛo/v/-.
The suffixed form*koṛg-(short vowel probably already in PGn) had an adjective meaning 'newly sprouted'.

Additional Forms: Also Pengokuplimound of earth; Mandakupki-to fill

Notes: "Metathese of voice" in PPM and also in KondaguRi(BB) is probably due to contamination with*guṭ-'short'.

External (SDR) data shows the original root to be*kut-. The formkund-, met in Pengo and  Manda, may represent another (although unparalleled) root with the meaning 'to strike with fist',  although both roots were contaminated, or else it is a secondary 'anti-causative' formation. Initialg-in Konda is unclear (contamination withguṭ-'to pound'?) Anyway, it is extremely hard  to deal with these roots, since there seems to be a very large 'family' of similar roots: namely, besides*kut-'to pierce', there is*kut-'to pound',*kuṭ-'to pierce',*gud-'to quarrel, fight',*guṭ-'fist, to pound'. Naturally, they have been so contaminated that it is almost impossible to reconstruct the original picture.

Additional Forms: Also Pengokutkahā-to strike one another with fists; Mandakund-(kunt-) to pierce, prod

Notes: Bisyllabic root.

Additional Forms: Also Pengokṛuk-(-t-) to sink (tr.);kṛū-(-t-) to sink into (mud); Mandakṛuk-to submerge, make to drown

Notes: Irregularg-in Manda.
Bisyllabic root; first consonant unclear (PPM points to*k-, Konda and PK point to*g-, but the latter may as well be secondary). Note: in PPM*kṇ-probably >*kṇ-, but*gṇ->gṛ-.
Bisyllabic root.
Pengo-nis extremely strange (misspelled?)
Causative conjugation in PPM and Konda.
The conjugation was causative, so devoicing is regular; in PPM we observe the almost regular "metathese of voice":*sēd_->*sēz->*zēc-.
Derivative of*sēd_-'to winnow', but on a very high level.

Additional Forms: Also Pengohōṇga-to enter (with motion particle); caus.hōṭpa-

Meaning: to wind, wind round, roll up

Notes: The only idea about the etymology is*leiŋ-oṇ-<*el-ŋ-+-oṇ-; in this case we may compare the forms with PDR*el-bone.

Meaning: spot made on forehead with turmeric

Notes: PK*maʔe<*mat_-he<*mad_-se.
Bisyllabic root.
Notes on correspondences: A rare type of bisyllabic nominal root with vocalic auslaut.

Notes: Bisyllabic root.
The form is reconstructed with *-d_k-, because *-t_k- > PK *-sk-.

Additional Forms: Also Pengogaṛcegirl; Mandanā-mgāṛmy daughter;āco-mgāṛ(pl.-mgahke) woman;gāṛeh(pl.-iŋ) girl
Also Pengomak-(-t-) to cause to lie, fell (tree)

Meaning: people belonging to the same side or party

Notes: Unexplainedv-in Gondi; contamination with other roots is not excluded (see DED 5265).
All the forms go back to*mari-s-(causative suffix). Bisyllabic root.
Bisyllabic root.
Kui-y-not quite clear; maybe it is a back-formation from*māŋga?
External parallels (withe) show the Pengo form is original.
Strange vocalism in Konda and PPM (a unique case).
In PPM probably shortening by analogy with plural*min-k-<*mīn-k-.
In Konda contamination withnipi.
Bisyllabic root.
Used mostly with suffixes:*mud_-s-> PG*muhc-,*mud_-l-> Kondamur_li-,*mud_-k-> PPM*murg-, PK*musk-.
Causative form in PPM. Kuimogo, Gondimoy'bud' may be borrowed from Telugu.

Bisyllabic root. In Gondi a progressive assimilation. In Kui*mrāl-would be expected. It is, however, not excluded that*-r-> PK*-ṛ-before*-l-(for example, because of dissimilation of two different dental resonants; the process is thus the opposite of the one in Gondi). In PPM only Pengo data is present, so the exact vocalism is unclear; however, since PG *koṛ-aɣ- > PPM*kṛɔy-, it is very much probable that the case here is similar.
Note that Kondamūnzi'nose' clearly belongs here and is related tomūnz-'to sniff' (4886), not tomūtu'beak' (5031), as Burrow and Emeneau put it.
Since the PK form is not certain, the base is only probably bisyllabic.
PK glottal stop probably reflects some kind of cluster; unfortunately, no external parallels.

Additional Forms: Also Pengo (B.)nāŋ(g)- (nāŋt-) to lick; Manda intens.nēbga-

Notes: The variant*neikuṛis possible if we suggest an earlier facultative development*-eik->*-ek-, since in Pengonikuṛis the correct variant.
Kondanāsumay not belong here; however, considering also such forms as Kuinōsuid., it may go back to*nōṇ-cuwith a suffix.
Pengonōṇ- is certainly not related tonūl'thread', as Burrow and Emeneau put it.
The causative form is*neŋ-s-, whence PK*neh-.

A very complicated root. PK form can go back to*nr_eʔ-<*ner_e-; PG form goes back to*nir_-n-. However, the status of Konda and Manda forms is unclear. Maybei-is a prefix (deictic base 'this'?), since loss of initialn-is impossible for both languages. In this case Kondainen<i-ner_(assimilation?), and Mandaineliŋ<*i-ner_-ŋ.

Additional Forms: Also Pengonec-(-c-) to fill; put in, insert

Notes: In Kondan-by contamination withmōpi.

Additional Forms: Also Pengomāpoin our region;mābeby us, with us

Notes: See*ēnfor details on Manda vocalism.
In Gondi-m-by analogy with the plural forms.
In Mandaīndeveloped by analogy with the oblique stem.

The original form was preserved in PK. In other groups*noḷ-was used only with suffixes, so  PPM*noḷ-nj->*nḷo-nj->*ṛonj-; PG*noḷ-nj-k->*nḷo-s-k->*ḷosk-.  In Konda the formlo-(causative type, from*noḷp-) probably developed by analogy withlonz-<*noḷ-nj-. There is no need to suggest that the root was originally bisyllabic, especially since it is clearly monosyllabic in PK.

Meaning: to scatter, sow broadcast, bail out (by sprinkling)

Additional Forms: Also Pengonōc-(nōcc-) to be ill, have fever;nōca vacaillness and emaciation;nōmerfever; Mandanūmerdisease, fever
Also Pengoṛuk-(-t-) to hide (tr.); Mandaṛuk-to hide (tr.)

Notes: Bisyllabic root.
The form in Gondi hasa-, but it is only present in L., and the reflexes of*o-in L. are not quite certain.
The root is hardly bisyllabic; PK and PPM forms are clearly influenced by*ri-'two'.

Additional Forms: Also Pengorokanone man;ronjelone woman;roki lōkone person;roceat one time;robeat one place; Mandarukanone man;runḍelone woman

Notes: PPM form is causative.
PPM*paz-is strange, since*-z-always <*-d_-. Cluster?
The metathese in PPM is caused by the causative character of the form.
Bisyllabic root.
Either these are two separate roots or this is a morphological alternation dating back to PDR.
Derivative*pāṇ-p-'song'.
PPM form is causative.
Bisyllabic root.
Mandapēmbaprobably belongs here (from*pēr-mb-), although this is not certain.
Bisyllabic root.
Bisyllabic root.

Meaning: to strain water from boiled rice

Notes: Gondi *-e- due to assimilation.
The form*pik-is suffixal (from*pik-p-or*pik-s-).
Usually used in the plural form*pīŋ.
Gondiposacannot belong here. It is probably a re-borrowing from IA.
Mandabūlaŋ<*bujl-<*pujl-<*pucl-.
Initial voiceless*p-in Gondi and Konda is due to contamination with*poŋ-'to swell'.
Bisyllabic root.
PG*boṭ-may be the result of contamination with PGn*boṭ-'spot, mark'.
Gondi*puh-can belong here if it goes back to*puṭ-s-. Konda and PPM forms are causative too.
Also Pengohak-naṛathroat
Bisyllabic root.
Bisyllabic root.

Meaning: to be in excess, left over

Notes: Derivative of*seip-.
Bisyllabic root.
Bisyllabic root.
Bisyllabic root. Some forms are re-borrowed from SDR; probably at least the Konda one, since  normally-r_-would be expected.
Bisyllabic root.
Bisyllabic root. The vocalic structure (*-a-e-) is seen primarily from the correspondence Gondi*tar-- PK*dä-<*tRe-.

Additional Forms: Also Pengoṛava,ṛovaheap of excavated earth; Mandaṛavaheap of excavated earth

Notes: A good bisyllabic root. In most subgroups reduction caused either the loss oft-(Konda, PPM) or-r_-(PK). The word had a causative conjugation in PGn, which may have contributed to the reduction.

Additional Forms: Also Mandatēr-(-t-) to lie, lie down

Notes: Derivative of*tin-'to eat'.
Bisyllabic root.
External parallels in PKG.

Additional Forms: Also Pengocōc-(cōcc-)/tōc-(tōcc-) to show; Mandatūc-to show

Notes: PG*tuh-k-<*tum-k-; Konda-p-because of the causative form.

Additional Forms: Also Pengotūk-(-t-) to hang (tr.);ḍūg-to hang down, (head) to nod; Mandatrūk-to swing (tr.)

Notes: Metathese in PPM.
Mandauliis probably either borrowed from or influenced by-l-languages.
Bisyllabic root.

Additional Forms: Also Pengoūṭpa-to give to drink; Mandaūṭ-to give to drink

Notes: Bisyllabic root.

Additional Forms: Also Pengoūp-(-t-) to cause to fly

Notes: Bisyllabic root.
Bisyllabic root.

Meaning: a trap for peacocks and hares

Notes: Also Pengovey-oṭilip
Bisyllabic root.
Bisyllabic root.

Additional Forms: Also Pengoṛēk-(-t-) to lay on the back

Notes: Bisyllabic root.
Also Pengovenba-(-t-), Mandavenba-to ask, inquire
Bisyllabic root.
Manda-p-is strange, but suffixal anyway.

Initial*b-in both PPM and PK, as Burrow and Emeneau state, is due to re-borrowing of both items from local Oriya, where it has been in turn borrowed previously with an initialb-. Actually, one can speak rather of Oriya influence on the form than of a direct borrowing.
Cf. also PKK*vēŋ-(caus.*vēk-) "to spread" - if it belongs here, the original root is*vē-with the approximate meaning "to extend, spread".
Bisyllabic root.
Metathese in PPM.
